g.text: he portable consumer electronics revolution has driven the
development of Li-ion batteries for efﬁcient energy
strong interest in developing cost-effective, rapidly recharging
Li-ion batteries suitable for long range electric vehicles
cathodes constitute a substantial portion of the volume and
cost of a battery signiﬁcant effort has been focused on the
materials that can retain structural integrity after repeated
electrochemical cycling of a material depends critically on the
initial structure and crystal stability. The presence and stability
of channels for fast Li-ion diffusion in cathode materials is an
important design criterion for developing next-generation
cathode materials for Li-ion batteries with higher capacity
and long-term energy storage performance. Understanding
nanoscale distribution of all of the elements that makeup Li-ion
battery cathodes—especially Li ions—as a function of different
synthesis procedures and extents of electrochemical cycling is a
critical step towards developing new materials.
Li-rich layered cathode materials with the general formulae
is considered to be a phase mixture of the trigonal Li
of these structures can be represented as repeating layers of
transition metal ions, O and Li. Recently, compositional
segregation of Ni to surfaces and grain boundaries within
some particles and partitioning of Mn away from Ni-rich
of high-angle annular dark-ﬁeld scanning transmission electron
the Ni-rich regions were shown to be consistent with an
R-3m phase and the Ni-deﬁcient regions a C2/m phase
Electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) analysis has indicated
a 7:9 Ni:Mn ratio (0.77) in the Ni-rich regions, best matching
, and a 5:42 Ni:Mn ratio (0.12) in the
matched an R-3m structure, with the exception of three peaks
no detailed information was found on the distribution of Li, or of
its correlation to other elements in the lattice, within the
Under battery charge–discharge cycling, layered Li
cathodes were observed to develop a thin surface
reconstruction layer, featuring structural transformation, Mn and
Ni enrichment, oxygen vacancy formation and Li depletion
Due to the structural and chemical change of the thin surface
layer, it is believed to be a likely main contributor to voltage
. Furthermore, it has been proven that the surface layer
continues to grow in thickness during continuous cycling
EDS analysis of cycled layered Li
indicated composition variations even within the thin surface
mechanism and seek a means to suppress the surface
reconstruction, requires monitoring the evolution of all
elements quantitatively at different states of cycling. However,
despite substantial characterization efforts in previous studies,
quantifying lithium depletion and subtle changes in oxygen
concentration in the surface layer have been proven to be
the most promising candidates for hybrid electric vehicle
a spinel structure with ordered P4
depending on the post-synthesis annealing temperature
This order–disorder phase transformation is expected to occur
during higher temperature annealing as a result of generation or
elimination of oxygen vacancies, by affecting the presence of
is shown to have better electrochemical performance than the
ordered spinel, owing to its higher electronic conductivity in the
presence of increased disordered phase and/or Mn
The common obstacle to using these materials is capacity and
voltage fading, believed to be closely related to a gradual
structural evolution, governed by the spatial distribution of Li
ions and their correlation with other ions in the lattice. Therefore,
one of the great challenges facing the development of these
high-voltage cathode materials for Li-ion batteries is to locate
the spatial distribution of ions with sub-nanometre-scale
spatially map the transition metal cations within Li-ion battery
cathodes, but these techniques do not have sufﬁcient sensitivity to
map Li at sub-nanometre scales, especially in three-dimensional
(3D). Atom probe tomography (APT) is uniquely capable of
for the Li, the O, and the transition metal cations
uniformcation distribution, providing a baseline evaluation of the
ability of APT in unambiguously analysing the Li distribution in
With this goal in mind, we provide here the ﬁrst evidence for
resolved mapping of Li, Ni, Mn and O in two categories of the
advanced Li-ion battery cathode materials: layered-Li[Li
compared with obtain insights towards mechanisms for cycling
LNMO—were analysed using STEM imaging and EDS mapping.
An annular dark-ﬁeld STEM image and EDS maps of a typical
layered-LNMO particle are shown in Fig. 1a–e providing a clear
evidence of non-uniform distribution of Ni and Mn within a
nanoparticle. A layered-LNMO nanoparticle was subsequently
analysed with APT using 20-pJ laser pulse energy to image and
quantify Li, Ni, Mn and O distributions. In the atom-probe
mass-to-charge spectra of layered-LNMO, elemental peaks of
tion to molecular species peaks for O
Of the total ion counts, 80.12% corresponded to elemental
evaporation of Li, Ni, Mn and O. Out of all the molecular
